(a) Diagram 2 shown above represents a particle-level view of liquid <math alttext="X e"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Xe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms.

(i) In the box in diagram 1, draw a particle-level view that represents a vessel that contains only solid <math alttext="X e"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Xe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(ii) In the box in diagram 2, draw a particle-level view that represents a vessel containing only gaseous <math alttext="X e"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Xe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Let <math alttext="P"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="V"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the pressure and volume of the <math alttext="X e, gas"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Xe</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the container in diagram 3. If a piston is used to reduce the volume of the gas to <math alttext="The fraction V over 2"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> at a constant temperature, what is the new pressure in the container in terms of the original pressure, <math alttext="P"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(c) Describe what happens to the average speed of the <math alttext="X e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Xe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms in the container in diagram 3 as the original volume <math alttext="V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is reduced to <math alttext="The fraction V over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> at a constant temperature.
